title: Misunderstanding
objective: To help players develop their communication and conflict resolution skills by navigating a misunderstanding with a friend.
scenario: A friend might be upset because they think the player did not show up to a planned event, when in fact there was a miscommunication and the player thought the event was on a different day.

options.text: It's not my fault you got the time wrong. You should have double-checked with me.
I'm sorry for the miscommunication. I thought we were meeting at a different time. Let's reschedule for another day.
I don't understand why you're upset. Can't you just wait for a bit longer?
I can understand why you're frustrated. Can you tell me more about what happened?

title: Walk in Their Shoes
objective: To help players understand different perspectives and emotions by putting themselves in someone else's shoes.
scenario: Your friend is upset because they were not invited to a party.

options.text: A. 'I'm sorry, I didn't realize you wanted to go to the party. I would have invited you if I had known.'
B. 'I didn't invite you because I thought you wouldn't want to come. I didn't mean to hurt your feelings.'
C. 'Why are you upset? It's just a party. There will be other events you can attend.'
D. 'I can understand why you're feeling upset. Can you tell me more about how you're feeling?'

title: Supportive Co-Worker
objective: To help players develop their empathy and support skills by navigating a co-worker's difficult situation. The goal is to create a supportive work environment where the co-worker feels valued and understood, while also ensuring that work tasks are completed effectively.
scenario: Your co-worker has been going through a difficult time at home and has been making mistakes at work. Your boss is upset and has asked you to talk to your co-worker about their performance.

options.text: You need to step up your game. Your performance has been unacceptable lately.
I understand that you've been going through a tough time at home. Let's talk about how we can support you and improve your work performance.
You're letting the team down with your poor performance. We need to see improvement or there may be consequences.
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through a difficult time. Can you tell me more about what's going on and how we can help?

title: Family Gathering
objective: The objective of this scenario is to practice empathy and active listening skills in a family setting. The player's task is to approach a relative who appears upset and engage them in a conversation to understand their feelings.
scenario: You're at a family gathering and notice that one of your relatives is sitting alone and appears upset. You approach them and ask if everything is okay.

options.text: A. You seem upset. What's going on?
Why are you sitting here all alone?
You're bringing everyone down with your negative energy.
Come on, let's join the others and have some fun.

title: Difficult Diagnosis
objective: To help players develop their empathy and active listening skills by navigating a conversation with a friend who has just received a difficult medical diagnosis.
scenario: The player's character is having a conversation with a friend who has just received a difficult medical diagnosis. The friend is feeling overwhelmed and scared, and the player must navigate the conversation in a way that shows empathy, active listening, and support.

options.text: A. Don't worry, I'm sure you'll be fine. People beat cancer all the time.
Well, at least it's not a terminal diagnosis, right?
I'm so sorry to hear that. How are you feeling right now?
I know this must be really scary for you. What can I do to support you?

title: Cultural Misunderstanding
objective: To help players develop their empathy and communication skills by navigating a cultural misunderstanding with a coworker.
scenario: Your coworker might be offended because you used a gesture that is considered rude in their culture.

options.text: A. I don't understand why you're so upset. It's just a harmless gesture in my culture.
I'm sorry if I offended you. Can you explain why the gesture I used is considered rude in your culture?
I had no idea that gesture was considered rude in your culture. Sorry about that.
I didn't mean to offend you. Let's just move past this and focus on our work.

title: Conflict Resolution
objective: To help players develop conflict resolution skills by navigating a conversation with someone they have had a disagreement or conflict with.
scenario: You and your roommate have been arguing lately because they have been leaving their dishes in the sink for days without cleaning them. You have tried talking to them about it, but they haven't changed their behavior. The tension between you has been growing, and you feel like you can't relax in your own home.

options.text: A. I understand that you're busy, but it's not fair for me to always have to clean up after you. Can we come up with a system that works for both of us?
I'm sorry it seems like I'm nagging you. I just want to make sure we're both doing our part to keep the apartment clean.
You're being ridiculous. It's not that hard to clean up after yourself.
I understand that you're busy, but it's important that we both contribute to keeping the apartment clean. Can we work together to find a solution that works for both of us?

title: Workplace Diversity
objective: To help players develop diversity and inclusion skills by navigating a conversation with a coworker who has experienced discrimination or microaggressions in the workplace.
scenario: Your co-worker has told you they have been experiencing discrimination and microaggressions.

options.text: A. I'm sorry to hear that. Have you considered reporting this to HR? Let me know how I can help.
I'm sorry to hear that you're going through this. I'm here for you and want to help in any way I can. Let me know if there's anything you need from me.
I'm sorry to hear that you've been experiencing discrimination and microaggressions. I want to support you in any way I can. Please let me know what you need.
I'm so sorry to hear that you've been experiencing discrimination and microaggressions. That must be really tough. I'm here for you and committed to helping in any way I can.

title: Teen Independence
objective: Encourage emotional intelligence in communicating desires for more independence from parents
scenario: You're a teenager who wants more freedom and independence from your parents. You're tired of feeling like you're constantly being monitored and restricted, and you want to be able to make your own decisions about how you spend your time. Your parent expresses concern for your safety.

options.text: A. I want more independence, can we work together to find a way to gradually increase it?
I need more freedom, can we talk about finding a balance?
I'm tired of always asking for permission, can we find a way to slowly give me more independence?
I want to make more decisions for myself, can we discuss some ways to do that while still following the rules?
